questions.text: Identify the lymphatic structure from the histology section given below?
Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below:
questions.explanation:
Layers of the cerebellar cortex

Molecular (plexiform) layer

Purkinje cell layer

Granular layer

It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells.

It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells.

The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells, along with a few larger Golgi cells.

These nerve cells are of two types:

(a) Basket cells

(b) Stellate cells.

The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei.

Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage

Fibrocartilage

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

questions.text: The cell marked in the below slide is inhibitory to
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Location

Cerebellar cortex (between molecular & granular layers)

Neurotransmitter

GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid)

Function

Inhibitory regulation of deep cerebellar nuclei

Target

Deep nuclei of cerebellum

Significance

Helps coordinate fine motor control by regulating output from deep cerebellar nuclei

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match:
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Location

Found in the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cavity.

Cell Types

Ciliated columnar cells, goblet cells, basal cells, and brush cells.

Function

Mucociliary clearance – Cilia move mucus upward, trapping and removing debris.

Lamina Propria

A loose connective tissue layer beneath the epithelium, not part of the epithelial layer.

Pathological Relevance

Loss of cilia function leads to chronic respiratory infections (e.g., in Kartagener syndrome).

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is secreted by the cell marked ‘X’ in the image?
questions.explanation:
Cell Type

Location

Hormone Secreted

Function

Follicular cells

Line the thyroid follicles

Thyroxine (T3, T4)

Regulates metabolism.

Parafollicular (C) cells

Between follicles

Calcitonin

Lowers blood calcium by inhibiting osteoclasts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding bones is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone

options.label: B
options.text: Collagen is synthesized in bone osteoblasts

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium phosphate is one of the major inorganic mineral

questions.correct_answer: C. Bone mainly contains type 2 collagen
questions.explanation:
Component

Function

Cells

Osteoblasts (bone formation), Osteocytes (maintenance), Osteoclasts (resorption)

Collagen Type

Type I collagen is the primary structural protein in bone

Inorganic Component

Hydroxyapatite (Calcium phosphate) provides bone rigidity

Bone Matrix

Composed of organic (collagen and proteins) and inorganic (minerals) components

questions.text: Which type of collagen is present in cartilage?
questions.explanation:
Collagen Type

Location

Function

Type I

Bone, skin, tendons, ligaments, cornea

Provides tensile strength

Type II

Cartilage (hyaline, elastic, fibrocartilage), vitreous humor

Provides resistance to pressure

Type III

Reticular fibers (skin, blood vessels, fetal tissue)

Provides structural support

Type IV

Basement membrane

Forms structural network in BM

questions.text: The inner layer of the fallopian tube is covered by:
questions.explanation:
Layer

Structure

Function

Mucosa

Ciliated columnar epithelium with secretory (peg) cells

Helps in ovum transport and secretion of nutrients

Muscularis

Inner circular and outer longitudinal smooth muscle layers

Peristalsis aids in ovum movement

Serosa

Outer peritoneal covering

Provides structural integrity

questions.text: Identify which of the following structure is a merocrine gland:
questions.explanation:
Feature

Merocrine Glands

Apocrine Glands

Holocrine Glands

Other Name

Eccrine glands

Modified sweat glands (e.g., mammary glands)

-

Cell Membrane Integrity

Membrane is intact

Secretions covered by cell membrane

Entire cell membrane is lost

Secretions

Released without loss of cell membrane

Released along with apical part of cell membrane

Whole cell is lost; becomes sebum

Mechanism of Secretion

Exocytosis

Blebs are formed; secretion is part of the cell membrane

Breakdown of entire cell, organelles become secretions

Examples

Salivary glands

Mammary gland (modified sweat gland)

Sebaceous glands

Function

Thermoregulation (e.g., sweat)

Involved in secretion of milk (in modified sweat glands)

Lubrication of skin (sebum secretion)

questions.text: Match the receptors with their correct function: 1. Ruffini corpuscle A. Vibration 2. Merkel cells B. Sustained pressure 3. Pacinian corpuscle C. Stretching 4. Meissner’s corpuscle D. Fine touch
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - 1C, 2B, 3A, 4D

questions.text: Identify the markers in the given slide:

options.label: A
options.text: A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland

options.label: B
options.text: A- Arrector pilorum, B- Eccrine sweat gland, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland

options.label: C
options.text: A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Apocrine gland, D-Sebaceous gland

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland

questions.text: Histological section is given below. Identify the marked cell.
questions.explanation:
Layers of the cerebellar cortex

Molecular (plexiform) layer

(Options A, B)

Purkinje cell layer

Granular layer

(Option D)

It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells.

It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells.

The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells, along with a few larger Golgi cells.

These nerve cells are of two types:

(a) Basket cells

(b) Stellate cells.

The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei.

Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory.
